nodes.title: Electrochemical Performance Analysis of CP80 and CA80
nodes.text:
Fig. 7. a) Cyclic voltammetry profile of CP80 and CA80 at 10 mV/s. b, d) Voltage profile of CP80 and CA80 during Li-plating/stripping test at 40 and 80 mA/cm<sup>2</sup> and cycling rate of C/2, c) Nyquist plots of CP80 and CA80 in Li symmetrical cells at 70 -C and the equivalent circuit model used for the fitting.

that CA80 shows a lower overpotential (61 mV) than CP80 (173 mV), indicating lower overall resistance which includes the bulk electrolyte resistance and electrode/electrolyte interface resistance. While the first one was analyzed in the previous section, the latter was studied by recording the impedance spectra of CP80 and CA80 in symmetrical Li cells. As depicted in [Fig. 7](#page-6-0)c, it is evident that the second semicircle at low-frequency region, ascribed to the Li metal/electrolyte resistance, is considerably smaller in CA80 than in CP80. The area-specific resistance was calculated to be 2,263 and 270 U cm2 for CP80 and CA80 respectively. Thus, it can be concluded that heat treatment of LLZO improves the Li metal/ electrolyte interface. This is also confirmed by comparing the impedance spectra of the cells recorded after the plating/stripping test, shown in Fig. S.3. In addition to the lower overpotential, the voltage profile during the 500 h of cycling, as presented in Fig. S.4, remains flatter and more stable in CA80 compared to CP80. This implies a more homogenous and uniform Li plating and stripping, bringing out the improvements of the CPEs on the solid state battery (SSB) performance. The plating/stripping test for both cells was continued at a higher current (80 mA/cm2 ) and the overpotentials were presented in [Fig. 7](#page-6-0)d. The overpotential profile of CA80 is steady and has a rather low amplitude, while the one of CP80 is unstable with high amplitudes up to 5 V. In addition, CP80 was short circuited after 270 h while CA80 continues cycling for over 800 h. Such high cyclability despite low ionic conductivity could be attributed to the high mechanical properties of the CPE membranes. The significant difference in the performance at different current densities evidently show that the improvements in the Li plating and stripping are more pronounced at higher current densities, as the Li metal/electrolyte interface would play a bigger role in uniform Li plating.
nodes.summary: This section details the electrochemical performance of CP80 and CA80, including cyclic voltammetry, voltage profiles during Li-plating/stripping, and impedance spectroscopy. It highlights CA80's superior performance with lower overpotential, improved interface stability, and higher cyclability compared to CP80, especially at higher current densities.

nodes.title: Concluding Remarks and Future Work
nodes.text:
## 4. Concluding remarks

In the present work, which continues our previous study of LLZO heat treatment and its impact on its interfacial properties, it is shown that heat treatment clearly improves the morphological, mechanical, and Li transport properties of garnet-rich CPEs with high LLZO fraction (>80 wt%). The SEM analysis showed that the composites prepared with heat-treated LLZO are more homogenous and have less particle agglomeration when compared to composites with pristine LLZO. NMR results show that the heat treatment of LLZO had a negative effect on Liþ exchange between LLZO and the polymer matrix, indicating that the Liþ exchange is more affected by the presence of LiOH in the interface, rather than the faster Liþ dynamics of LLZO after heat treatment. The comparison of ionic conductivities reveals that ion conduction happens mainly through the polymeric phase because the grain boundary resistance is too high for facile ion transport through the inorganic phase. LLZO heat treatment improved the ionic conductivity of garnet-rich CPEs, and this improvement was more significant when LLZO content was increased, highlighting the negative effect of LLZO agglomeration and phase segregation on obstructing the Liþ pathways. Therefore, the more homogenous microstructure of CPEs with heat-treated LLZO is responsible for their higher ionic conductivity.

Despite improvements in morphology and ionic conductivity, ion conduction is mainly happening through the polymer phase, and the high ionic conductivity of LLZO is not extracted in CPEs, even when the LLZO fraction reaches 90 wt%. Based on the hypothesis that the grain boundary resistance is the main issue in this matter, we propose using 1D and 2D ceramic networks to facilitate ion conduction through the inorganic phase. These systems will be investigated in a future work.
nodes.summary: This section summarizes the findings that heat treatment of LLZO improves the morphological, mechanical, and Li transport properties of garnet-rich CPEs. It also identifies that ion conduction primarily occurs through the polymer phase and proposes future research directions involving 1D and 2D ceramic networks to enhance inorganic phase ion conduction.
